JACOBSON* Halcon SD Group (Texas Eastern Co.), 1 Philips Parkway, Montvale, NJ 07646 (U.S.A.) Summary Rhodium(I) complexes in the presence of phosphine-amides and phosphine-amines were active catalysts for the hydroformylation of form- aldehyde to glycol aldehyde. A variety of polar organic solvents and polar- nonpolar mixtures were found to be suitable for this reaction. The effect of changes in rhodium phosphine ancillary nucleophile ring size, rhodium precursor, anionic ligand, phosphine :rhodium ratio and water concentration on formaldehyde conversion and glycol aldehyde selectivity were studied. A practical, recyclable system was devised by combining a lipophilic phosphine-amide with a Rh(I) cocatalyst and a mixed polar-nonpolar solvent system. A possible mechanistic interpretation of these observations is proposed. Introduction The use of synthesis gas as a feedstock for ethylene glycol synthesis has been an active area of study since the early 1970s. Despite the fact that ethylene prices have decreased dramatically with oil prices over the last several years, the volatility and unpredictability of these price swings com- bined with the limited petroleum resources availabile in the world, make this still an important long term area of research [1]. Union Carbide has published a long series of patents and papers on the direct ethylene glycol synthesis via synthesis gas [2]. However, even after many improvements, this reaction requires a high catalyst concentration and extremely high syngas pressures to obtain acceptable rates. These require- ments make the process unattractive commercially. An alternative route to ethylene glycol would involve formaldehyde hydroformylation to glycol aldehyde followed by hydrogenation [3]. Form- aldehyde can be easily synthesized from methanol (made from syngas) via either oxidation or dehydrogenation. Several workers, recognizing this, have used formaldehyde as a precursor to ethylene glycol. Rhodium-catalyzed *Present address: 7 Ironwood Road, Morristown, NJ 07960 (U.S.A.). 0304-5102/87/$3.50 Elsevier Sequoia/Printed in The Netherlands 164 formaldehyde hydrofonnylation to glycol aldehyde has been found to be much more active and selective than that with cobalt [4]. Spencer [5] and Goetz [6] have found that a reasonable rate and selectivity to glycol aldehyde via rhodium-catalyzed hydrofonnylation could only be achieved in JV,N-disubstituted amide solvents. Mawby et al. [7] had previously found that the rate of the migatory carbon monoxide insertion reaction of CH^n- (00)5 was increased by a factor of 104 when the solvent was changed from mesitylene to DMF. Wax and Bergman [8] have recently provided evidence that donor solvents such as tertiary amides can attack and bind to the metal center as the organic group migrates, thus providing 'solvent catalysis' of the alkyi migration reaction. In other words, the nucleophilic solvent is acting to drive the alkyi migration, a critical step in glycol aldehyde formation. The high boiling points of tertiary amides, instability of certain amides under CO and at higher temperatures, and solubility of glycol aldehyde prevent the separation of the product glycol aldehyde and the homogeneous rhodium catalyst in a practical process, thus preventing recycle of the catalyst. We questioned whether a nucleophilic solvent is necessary to effect glycol aldehyde formation. Could a bidentate ligand be synthesized in which one end is the necessary phosphorus of a tertiary phosphine ligand and the other end is a nucleophilic ligand which could act as a 'ligand catalyst'? It was decided to prepare various phosphine-amides, phosphine-amines and phosphine-phosphine oxides with various ring sizes and then study form- aldehyde hydrofonnylation in a variety of solvents [9]. Results and discussion Most of the phosphine-amides were synthesized by a modification of the method of Dubois et al. [10] in which a phosphorus-hydrogen bond adds to carbon-carbon double bonds of vinyl derivatives in the presence of free radical initiators, e.g.: AIBN PPh^H + CH2=CHC(0)N(CH3)2 ^ ^ > PPh^CH^CON^), The phosphine PPhz N ^ was synthesized by the following reaction: OTHF / \ PPhzCl + H-1S > PPha-N .> + HC1-DMAP In principle, the amide end of the ligand can be bound to the metal through the nitrogen or the oxygen. However, several studies [11] have shown that rhodium and other Group VIII metals bind to amides through 165 the oxygen rather than the nitrogen moiety. In this work, oxygen coordina- tion will be assumed to determine the size of the ring formed by rhodium, the phosphorus of the phosphine and the amide group (Table 1). Catalytic quantities of phosphine-amides in combination with rhodi- um(I) precursors were found to be highly selective to glycol aldehyde for the following hydroformylation reaction in a variety of solvents (Tables 2 - 4). HaCO + CO + Ha > HOCHaCHO It can be seen that the phosphine-amide in acetonitrile is almost an order of magnitude more selective to glycol aldehyde with the ligand Jv,.N-dimethyl-3- (diphenylphosphino)propionamide than with triphenylphosphine (Spencer's system). The comparison with ethyldiphenylphosphine, a corresponding alkyldiphenylphosphine, is even more dramatic. A comparison of the phos- phine-amide and triphenylphosphine in other polar solvents such as tetra- glyme,_ acetone and sulfolane shows the greater selectivity of the phosphine- amides to glycol aldehyde. Only in JV,JV-disubstituted amide solvents is the difference between tri- phenylphosphine and the phosphine-amide much smaller (Table 3). The reason is that apparently the amide solvent in the triphenylphosphine case and the phosphine-amide in our system are very comparable in their ability to catalyze glycol aldehyde formation. Polar solvents with protic behavior, such as ethylene glycol, and nonpolar solvents, such as m-xylene and tolu- ene, are much less selective to glycol aldehyde. Ring size The size of the ring formed by the rhodium and phosphine-amide is very important in determining both the conversion of formaldehyde and the selectivity to glycol aldehyde (Table 1, acetonitrile solvent in all exam- ples). The A?,^-dimethyl-3-(diphenylphosphino)propionamide ligand (six- membered ring) is the most effective for both conversion of formaldehyde and selectivity to glycol aldehyde. Its selectivity to glycol aldehyde contrasts sharply with ^v"-(diphenylphosphino)-2-pyrrolidinone which forms a five- membered ring. Its lack of selectivity to glycol aldehyde corresponds very closely to the ethyldiphenylphosphine blank, indicating that the amide is not functioning to catalyze glycol aldehyde formation. Enhancement of catalytic activity due to the presence of bidentate ligands is not unprecedented. For example, diphosphine chelate rings with certain ring sizes have served as cocatalysts for hydrogenation [13], hydro- formylation [14] and decarbonylation [15] reactions. During the course of this work, an example of propylene hydroformylation appeared in which a bidentate phosphine-phosphine oxide served as a co-catalyst and gave enhanced linear-to-branched ratios and higher long-term activity than the triarylphosphine ligands [16]. Rhodium precursor In most cases, the phosphine-amide was reacted with a precursor rhodium complex to generate the active catalytic species in situ. Various precursors such as Rl^CC^Cl;, B^CgH^Clz, Rh2(ethylene)4d2 and Rh(CO)(Cl)(PPh3)2 were used in the same solvent for comparison (Table 5). The Rh2(CO)4d2 species seems to give somewhat greater selectivity to glycol aldehyde and conversion of formaldehyde than Rh2(CgH4)4Cl2 or Rh2(ethylene)4Cl2. The much lower selectivity of Rh(Cl)(CO)(PPh3)2 to glycol aldehyde must be ascribed to the poorer selectivity of a rhodium- triphenylphosphine complex than a rhodium-phosphine-amide complex to glycol aldehyde in acetonitrile solvent. These complexes were found to have activity and selectivity comparable to the respective precursor plus a two- to three-fold ratio of phosphine-amide (Tables 3 and 5). Anionic ligand Except for the chloride case (uida supra), the complexes with various anions were generated in situ by addition of the corresponding acid to the Rh(CO)2(acac) complex (Table 4). The acetylacetonate ligand is readily protonated to acetylacetone by the strong acid. The trifluoroacetate anion showed much higher activity with greater selectivity to glycol aldehyde than the chloride ion under identical condi- tions (Table 6). The methanesulfonate and benzenesulfonate ions were inferior to the chloride in selectivity to glycol aldehyde. The greater lability of the trifluoroacetate compared to the chloride [18] may open coordina- tion sites on the rhodium and be responsible for its greater activity. Phosphine-amide :rhodium ratio A 2-3:1 phosphine-amide :rhodium ratio seemed to be the optimum to obtain a maximum selectivity of glycol aldehyde (Table 7). Lower ratios resulted in catalyst decomposition, and higher ratios resulted in higher methanol selectivities and lower glycol aldehyde selectivities. Addition of water The addition of water was detrimental to glycol aldehyde selectivity in the favored acetonitrile solvent system. The selectivity to glycol aldehyde dropped two-thirds even with only 46 wt.% aqueous formaldehyde (Table 8). Anionic rhodium complexes Up to this point, our reactions have involved the proposed formation of RhX(CO)(PR3)2 (X = CFaCOz, Cl) as the precursor to the active catalytic species. During the course of our studies, Monsanto's work appeared which involved anionic rhodium complexes generated by catalytic amounts of ter- tiary amines [19]. These systems were extremely active for glycol aldehyde formation even in the presence of excess triarylphosphine ligands. Therefore, we used several concentrations of tertiary amine in our Rh^CC^C^phosphine-amide (1:3 ratio) system and obtained high activity even at 100 C (Table 9). Recycle of rhodium-phosphine-amide catalyst No investigators in the area of formaldehyde hydroformylation have addressed the problem of recycle of the expensive rhodium catalyst. The high boiling point (120 C, 12 mmHg) and instability [4] of glycol aldehyde make its continuous distillation from the rhodium catalyst unfeasible. It was decided to employ a mixed solvent system which would involve a lower-boiling polar solvent (acetonitrile), a higher-boiling nonpolar solvent (m-xylene), and a small amount of a second low-boiling solvent which would break the acetonitrile-methanol azeotrope (diethyl ether). Initially, it was attempted to hydrogenate the glycol aldehyde using the homogeneous rhodium catalyst. These second stage hydrogenations met with no success using both the chloride and trifluoroacetate systems from 110 -140 C. Hydrogen pressures up to 211 atm were explored. The literature also indi- cates difficulty in aldehyde hydrogenations with homogeneous rhodium complexes [20]. Therefore, an alternative separation process was developed. After the hydroformylation reaction, the lower-boiling materials (acetonitrile, 172 diethyl ether and methanol) were distilled at 70 C, 350 mm under a carbon monoxide sparge. The carbon monoxide sparge was required to prevent decomposition of the rhodium complex. The glycol aldehyde and unreacted formaldehyde precipitated from the m-xylene solution. As expected, the rhodium J?V,^V-dimethyl-3-(diphenylphosphino)propionamide complex migrated into the glycol aldehyde layer (Ex. 1, Table 10). However, we did demonstrate that the unreacted formaldehyde and glycol aldehyde could be separated in acetonitrile solvent at 83 C. The monomeric form- aldehyde was distilled with acetonitrile, leaving the glycol aldehyde behind. The glycol aldehyde was then dissolved in ethylene glycol and fed to a trickle-bed reactor packed with ruthenium on carbon at 160 C, 34 atm hydrogen, where it was hydrogenated (98% conversion) according to litera- ture methods[21]. It was decided to synthesize a ligand as close in structure as possible to JV,A^-dimethyl-3-(diphenylphosphino)propionamide and yet tailor it to have a high solubility in nonpolar organic solvents. Therefore, it was decided to put an organic 'tail' on the ligand making it lipophilic. The synthesis of a phosphine-amide with an eighteen-carbon 'tail' was accomplished via the base-catalyzed amidolysis ofethyl-2-(diphenylphosphino)propionate: NaOMe PPh2(CH2)2C(0)OC2Hs + NH(CH3)(Ci8H37) -> 100 '0 173 The rhodium lv-methyl-^v-octadecyl-3-(diphenylphosphino)propion- amide system gave somewhat lower formaldehyde conversion with higher glycol aldehyde selectivity than its parent phosphine-amide (Table 10). The migration of rhodium into the glycol aldehyde layer is decreased by several orders of magnitude for both the chloride and the trifluoroacetate systems. Also, it is possible to recycle both systems with a 13% decrease in activity after the first cycle for the trifluoroacetate and a 25% decrease for the chloride system. However, after the first cycle the selectivity to glycol aldehyde seems to even improve for the trifluoroacetate system, while remaining about constant for the chloride. Rhodium phosphine-phosphine oxide catalysts During the course of this work, National Distillers found that in the presence of a rhodium(I)-triarylphosphine catalyst and a large excess of tri- alkylphosphine oxide, a tertiary amide solvent is not necessary to obtain reasonable selectivities to glycol aldehyde in formaldehyde hydroformyl- ation [22]. Also, a Union Carbide patent [16] appeared claiming a rhodi- um(I)-phosphine-phosphine oxide catalyst which enhanced the activity and linear-to-branched selectivity for propylene hydroformylation. Therefore, we decided to prepare a phosphine-phosphine oxide ligand by the radical-catalyzed (AIBN) addition of dioctylphosphine oxide to vinyl diphenylphosphine [23]: AIBN P(0)(CsHi7)2H + (CH2=CH)PPh2 > PPh^CH^P^XCgH^), Very poor selectivities (~15%) to glycol aldehyde and good selectivities to methanol were found for both the chloride and trifluoroacetate systems (Table 11). The addition of a large excess of trioctylphosphine oxide or tri- butylphosphine oxide to the rhodium(I)-triarylphosphine catalyst system gives better glycol selectivities (16 - 43%), but it is still much worse than the tertiary amide system. Because of these poor glycol aldehyde selectivities, this system was studied no further. Rhodium-phosphine-amine catalysts During our study of rhodium-phosphine-amides, a Monsanto study [19] appeared of formaldehyde hydroformylation to glycol aldehyde in high conversions (~90%) catalyzed by a rhodium(I)-trialkylamine triphenylphos- phine. The advantage of this process is that excess triphenylphosphine {e.g. 30:1 P:Rh) can be used to help stabilize the complex. The drawback is that it involves the addition of a basic amine, which catalyzes side reactions of the reactants and products such as aldol condensation [24], which results in poor glycol aldehyde selectivity (30% selectivity to 'heavies' in some cases). Glyceraldehyde, 1,3-dihydroxypropanone, erythrose, 1,3-trihydroxybutan- one, and also C5 and C6 byproducts were characterized. We proposed that a phosphine-amine may eliminate much of the aldol condensation, because the amine would be in close proximity to the metal and unavailable to catalyze aldol condensation of the glycol aldehyde. In the presence of phosphine-amides, excess triaryl- phosphine decreases the selectivity to glycol aldehyde and increases the selectivity to methanol (Table 5). 178 Mechanism Although we have not conducted any mechanistic studies, a reasonable mechanism for glycol aldehyde and methanol formation is outlined below. A hydroxymethyl rhodium complex is apparently formed from the reaction of an acidic rhodium hydride and pre-bound, possibly 'side-bound', form- aldehyde. Both the hydroxymethyl [26] and 'side-bound' formaldehyde [27] complexes have been isolated and characterized in various model sys- tems. The alternative formation of a rhodium-methoxy complex is also pos- sible as a source of methanol [28], but we believe its existence is unlikely [3]. A migratory CO insertion of the hydroxymethyl ligand apparently competes with irreversible reductive elimination to methanol (auxiliary ligands not shown): H HO I CO | || Rh-CHaOH ^ Rh-C-CHaOH CO CO \ I \ 1 I CHaOH H-CCH20H The inherently slow migratory CO insertion of the hydroxymethyl ligand [29] can dominate the reductive elimination pathway only in the presence of a strongly nucleophilic solvent or, in our case, a nucleophilic ligand. It is suggested that rhodium phosphine-amide or -amine catalysts enhance the rate of conversion of a hydroxymethylrhodium to a hydroxy- acetylrhodium species, which has only recently been isolated in a model system [30]. This enhancement of the migratory CO insertion reaction apparently results from an intramolecular, nucleophilic attack on the coordi- natively unsaturated organometallic center illustrated for the amide moiety: CHaOH 0 Or""1 0 OC-Rh-P CNRz^HOCHaC-'Rh^P C-NR; Previously for solvent catalysis, the role of the nucleophile was thought to be stabilization of the coordinatively unsaturated intermediate [7, 8], but 179 recent careful mechanistic work indicated that at least for a model alkyi manganese carbonyl system, the function of the nucleophile is only to catalyze the formation of the unsaturated acyi intermediate [31]. The size or *bite' of the rhodium-phosphine-amide ring system is important in order to deliver the nucleophilic amide in as facile a manner as possible. The inhibition of formaldehyde hydroformylation to glycol aldehyde by excess phosphine-amide or triarylphosphine argues for a 'dissociative' mechanism similar to that proposed for olefin hydroformylation [20] and found by Spencer for formaldehyde hydroformylation catalyzed by a large excess of triarylphosphine [5j. A dissociation of phosphine-amide becomes more unlikely with excess phosphine-amide, and sites are tied up which would be occupied by CO, formaldehyde, or left vacant. However, the selective hydroformylation of formaldehyde to glycol aldehyde is also catalyzed by a 3:1 phosphine-amine: rhodium ratio with a large excess of triarylphosphine. Apparently the phosphine-amine deproto- nates the acidic rhodium hydride catalyst, generating an anionic rhodium complex. This anionic catalyst can readily react with formaldehyde through nucleophilic attack to form the hydroxymethyl complex, similar to the rhodium-trialkylamine-triarylphosphine system [19]. The amine moiety in the phosphine-amine is apparently in closer proximity to the rhodium because of its 'chelate effect' than in the trialkylamine system, and is thus less available to catalyze aldol condensation. This may account for lower quantities of 'heavies' in the phosphine-amine system. The selectivity of the phosphine-amine system to glycol aldehyde is less sensitive to water concentration than the phosphine-aroide system. The amine of the phosphine-amine is apparently able to compete with water for the coordination sphere of the rhodium(III) much better than the amide of the phosphine-amide. A rhodium-catalyzed amide hydrolysis may also be a problem in the rhodium phosphine-amide system. Rhodium(I) complexes in the presence of phosphine-amides and phosphine-amines were active catalysts for the hydroformylation of formaldehyde to glycol aldehyde. A variety of polar organic solvents and polarnonpolar mixtures were found to be suitable for this reaction. The effect of changes in rhodium phosphine - ancillary nucleophile ring size, rhodium precursor, anionic ligand, phosphine :rhodium ratio and water concentration on formaldehyde conversion and glycol aldehyde selectivity were studied. A practical, recyclable system was devised by combining a lipophilic phosphine-amide with a Rh(I) cocatalyst and a mixed polar-nonpolar solvent system. coredata.dc:description: Rhodium(I) complexes in the presence of phosphine-amides and phosphine-amines were active catalysts for the hydroformylation of formaldehyde to glycol aldehyde. A variety of polar organic solvents and polarnonpolar mixtures were found to be suitable for this reaction. The effect of changes in rhodium phosphine - ancillary nucleophile ring size, rhodium precursor, anionic ligand, phosphine :rhodium ratio and water concentration on formaldehyde conversion and glycol aldehyde selectivity were studied. A practical, recyclable system was devised by combining a lipophilic phosphine-amide with a Rh(I) cocatalyst and a mixed polar-nonpolar solvent system. A possible mechanistic interpretation of these observations is proposed.
coredata.dc:title: Formaldehyde hydroformylation to glycol aldehyde via rhodium phosphine-amine and phosphine-amide catalysts
